messageBody:
## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-09-29T17:31:00Z
## Message ID: 20160929-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt continue. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux is above 10^5 pfu starting at 2016-09-27T16:50Z and again at 2016-09-29T16:30Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting at 2016-09-26T07:05Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2016-09-27T16:50:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes: 



NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Geomagnetic Storm
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-09-28T22:12:03Z
## Message ID: 20160928-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Ongoing space weather storm in the Earth's magnetosphere. Geomagnetic Kp index has reached level 6 (moderate) during the synoptic period 2016-09-28T18:00Z to 2016-09-28T21:00Z. 

The storm is caused by high speed stream starting at 2016-09-26T07:05Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO, polar and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's ring current and auroral regions can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2016-09-28T18:00:00-GST-001.

## Notes:

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for September 21, 2016 - September 27, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-09-28T20:42:59Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-09-21T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-09-27T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20160928-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at very low levels during this reporting period.     

Geomagnetic activity was at moderate levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=6 for the reporting period.  The Kp index reached value of Kp=6 during the synoptic period 2016-09-27T15:00Z to 2016-09-27T18:00Z.  This moderate geomagnetic storm was associated with the coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR at L1 around 2016-09-26 (see notifications 20160927-AL-003 and 20160927-AL-004).  The solar wind speed reached high values of 740 km/s on 2016-09-28.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu.   GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux is above 10^5 pfu starting at 2016-09-27T16:50Z. These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt was associated with the coronal hole high speed stream described above (see notifications 20160927-AL-001 and 20160927-AL-002).  

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevated electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.  

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed 

CMEs (>500 km/s):
Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed   

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-09-28T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2016-10-04T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming reporting period.  The active regions on the disk appear to have low magnetic complexity.  The geomagnetic activity is expected to be elevated  for the beginning of the upcoming week due to the coronal hole high speed stream described above.  

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for September 14, 2016 - September 20, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-09-21T19:19:51Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-09-14T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-09-20T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20160921-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There was 1 C-type CME (see details below).   The arrival from the CME starting on 2016-09-14T23:36Z was detected by STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC data on 2016-09-17T14:00Z (see notification 20160915-AL-001).  

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic period of 2016-09-20T00:00Z-03:00Z.  This slight increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with the coronal hole high speed stream arrival detected by DSCOVR at L1 around 2016-09-19.  The solar wind speed reached very high values of ~750 km/s on 2016-09-20.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES are elevated at the end of this reporting period due to the coronal high speed stream described above, but have remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):
Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2016-09-14T23:36Z     ~722            C              -122/-18               43                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-09-21T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2016-09-27T23:59Z

The solar and geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  The solar active regions on the Earth-facing side of the disk appear to have low magnetic complexity.  However, active region 12595, which is very close to the west limb, has began to produce C-class flares during 2016-09-21 and may provide further activity.  The geomagnetic activity has been slightly enhanced due to the coronal hole high speed stream arrival described above, but it is expected to decrease in the next few days.  

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score


NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (Spitzer, STEREO A)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-09-15T14:23:43Z
## Message ID: 20160915-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2016-09-14T23:36Z.

Estimated speed: ~722 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 43 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -122/-18 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates (see [1] in Notes).

Activity ID: 2016-09-14T23:36:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact Spitzer and STEREO A.  The leading edge of the CME will reach Spitzer at 2016-09-17T15:34Z and STEREO A at 2016-09-17T07:30Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME: 2016-09-14T23:36:00-CME-001):

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for September 07, 2016 - September 13, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-09-14T18:05:27Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-09-07T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-09-13T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20160914-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at very low levels during this reporting period.  There was 1 C-type CME (see details below).   

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period.

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES was elevated at the beginning of the reporting period and crossed the threshold of 10^5 pfu on 2016-09-07T13:00Z due to the coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR at L1 on 2016-09-01.  They began to slowly decrease after 2016-09-07 and have remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the rest of the reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.  

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed 

CMEs (>500 km/s):
Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2016-09-11T08:12Z     ~597            C                89/5                 12                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
 
## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-09-14T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2016-09-20T23:59Z

The solar and geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  The active regions on the solar surface appear to have low magnetic complexity.  The geomagnetic activity could become slightly enhanced due to a coronal hole high speed stream arrival on 2016-09-15 to 2016-09-16.

R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for August 31, 2016 - September 06, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-09-07T20:09:33Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-08-31T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-09-06T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20160907-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were 2 C-type CMEs (see details below).   

Geomagnetic activity was at moderate levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=6 for the reporting period.  Geomagnetic Kp index reached level 6 (moderate) during the synoptic periods starting on 2016-09-01T21:00Z  through 2016-09-02T06:00Z and again on 2016-09-03T03:00Z-06:00Z.  This elevation in geomagnetic activity was associated with the coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR at L1 on 2016-09-01 (see notifications 20160902-AL-001 and 20160903-AL-001).  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu several times during this reporting period and have remained elevated.  GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux was above 10^5 pfu for the first time starting at 2016-09-02T16:10Z, and has remained elevated for the entire reporting period crossing the threshold of 10^5 pfu several times.  These events of significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt were associated with the coronal hole high speed stream described above (see notifications 20160902-AL-002, 20160902-AL-003, 20160904-AL-001, and 20160906-AL-001).  

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes events in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.  

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed 

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2016-09-06T06:24Z     ~539            C               160/22                10                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
2016-09-06T08:54Z     ~674            C               120/-20               31                          STEREO A, SOHO                    
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-09-07T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2016-09-13T23:59Z

The solar and geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  Active regions on the Earth's facing side have been producing low B-class flares, but the active regions on the far side have been recently producing coronal mass ejections.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to decrease in the next few days as the effects of the coronal hole high speed stream subside.

## Notes:

C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-09-06T13:39:26Z
## Message ID: 20160906-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes continue in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux is above 10^5 pfu starting at 2016-09-06T13:00Z and has remained elevated for the past few days (see notifications 20160902-AL-002, 20160902-AL-004 and 20160904-AL-001).  

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by high speed stream starting at 2016-09-01T10:00Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2016-09-06T13:00:00-RBE-001.

## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Geomagnetic Storm
##

##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Ongoing space weather storm in the Earth's magnetosphere. Geomagnetic Kp index has reached level 6 (moderate) during the synoptic period 2016-09-03T03:00Z to 2016-09-03T06:00Z. 

The storm is caused by high speed stream starting at 2016-09-01T10:00Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO, polar and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's ring current and auroral regions can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2016-09-03T03:00:00-GST-001.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Geomagnetic Storm
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-09-02T12:26:35Z
## Message ID: 20160902-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Intensifying space weather storm in the Earth's magnetosphere. Geomagnetic Kp index has reached level 6 (moderate) during the synoptic periods 2016-09-02T21:00Z to 2016-09-02T00:00Z, 2016-09-02T00:00Z to 2016-09-02T03:00Z, and 2016-09-02T03:00Z to 2016-09-02T06:00Z. 

The storm is caused by high speed stream starting at 2016-09-01T10:00Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO, polar and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's ring current and auroral regions can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2016-09-01T21:00:00-GST-001.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for August 24, 2016 - August 30, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-08-31T21:41:15Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-08-24T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-08-30T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20160831-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at very low levels during this reporting period.  There was 1 C-type CME (see details below).   

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2016-08-23T18:00Z to 2016-08-24T03:00Z and was associated with a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR at L1 around 2016-08-23.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2016-08-30T03:12Z     ~585            C               -82/-7                13                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-08-31T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2016-09-06T23:59Z

The solar and geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  Currently, we are under the influence of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR at L1 around 2016-08-30 that could increase geomagnetic activity.  

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score
